ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to have literary discussions in French.

I improved my French reading, writing, and speaking skills, and gained an overview of some French literature from different countries and time periods. What was especially useful was Lauren Pinzka's handouts regarding French writing style, useful expressions, and common grammar mistakes, which allowed my essay writing to become much more formal and polished.
Lots of exposure to various types of French literature and authors of various decades.
I was exposed to a large body of literary work and my analysis skills as well as my discussion/debate skills were greatly improved.
I developed the ability to discuss and analyze  the literary techniques of french novels in french.
I learned how to analyze and discuss French literature and how to write literary essays with clear arguments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think it is a great way to improve auditory comprehension and speaking skills.

I liked the format of the course, which was almost entirely comprised of rigorous class discussion about themes, symbolism, and stylistic aspects of each text we read. My main complaint about the course this semester was the choice of books. The theme was "exile and return," which leads quite well into an exploration of non-French francophone literature (i.e. writers from former French colonies or occupied territories) especially from writers of color. Although we read a few books from that category around the end of the course, we also read "ourika" and "lettres d'une pruvienne," which essentially entailed white authors writing from the perspective of imaginary characters of color, and included insensitive language and portrayals of those characters' cultures. Although our discussions of these books clearly acknowledged the fact that they were problematic, I did not think that they spoke to the theme of the course, nor were they pedagogically useful. In general, the idea of having a theme for the course was interesting, but the selection of texts may have been more exciting if it was not limited as such.

Strengths: Interesting literature read--good discussions
Weaknesses: Classes were repetitive at times with how similarly structured/led each individual class was

This course should have a smaller class size. My section had too many people in too small of a room and it was difficult to have everyone involved in the discussions. This being said, I love the discussion-based structure of this class. You read a work/a section of a work (be prepared for large reading assignments) and then come into class and basically just share your thoughts and get into (friendly) arguments about your interpretation. It's a very fun intellectual environment. There are only 3 significant graded assignments, a presentation and 2 essays which are not that difficult and you have the opportunity to turn in a corrected version to get points back.

The amount of reading was challenging, but reading responses helped me process the text by writing about it. The course covered a diverse range of novels from vastly different time periods with different writing styles, which I thought was interesting. 

I was often frustrated by our class discussions, in which one or two students consistently dominated the conversation. I found it very difficult to jump in and participate. It was hard to stay motivated to complete all the readings when I often did not have the chance to demonstrate my knowledge in class.
Sometimes there were a few days where there was a lot of reading assigned that was hard to complete in the time given, especially when there was also a written assignment to complete that day.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes absolutely. Just be aware that it requires heavy reading.
Yes, if they are very interested in learning more about various kinds of French literature.

I would; it's not too hard and I think it can be really fun if you engage with it the right way. Don't stress too much about the essays and get help early on if you need it. Definitely learn to skim when it comes to the books because there's a lot of reading. Also be prepared to participate a lot in this course; if you're shy about speaking that's something to think about before taking this course.
I would recommend this class to a student who is very committed to reading extensively in French.
Yes, this course is a great way to further French language skills while exploring French literature.

extras.title: FREN 170 02 - Intro Study of French Lit
